node.title: How Do You Tell the World That Doomsday Has Arrived?
node.alt: Jennifer Lawrence and Leonardo DiCaprio are astronomers trying to sound the alarm for a comet heading toward Earth in the film “Don’t Look Up.”
node.description: A new film about a killer comet revives memories of a nail-biting night in The Times newsroom two decades ago.
node.content: ["One of the thus-far theoretical duties of the astronomer is to inform the public that something very big and horrible is about to happen: The sun will soon explode, a black hole has just wandered into Earth\u2019s path, hostile aliens have amassed an armada right behind the moon.", "In the new Netflix film \u201cDon\u2019t Look Up,\u201d a pair of astronomers, played by Leonardo DiCaprio and Jennifer Lawrence, assume this responsibility when they discover that a \u201cplanet-killing\u201d comet is headed straight for Earth and must spread the news.", "It doesn\u2019t go well. The president of the United States, played by Meryl Streep, is more concerned with her poll numbers. Television talk show hosts ridicule the scientists. Rich oligarchs want to exploit the comet\u2019s minerals. \u201cDon\u2019t Look Up\u201d may be the most cinematic fun anyone has had with the End of the World since Stanley Kubrick\u2019s 1964 classic black comedy, \u201cDr. Strangelove or: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Bomb.\u201d", "Watching it brought back my own experience reporting Really Bad news. In March of 1998, I was the new deputy science editor of The Times, and my doomsday audience was small but elite: The Times\u2019s top editors. I had been on the job for only a month. Nobody really knew me. My direct boss, the science editor, had taken the week off, leaving me in charge.", "And so, late in the afternoon on March 11, I walked into the 4:30 news meeting where editors pitch stories for the next day\u2019s front page and announced that we had a late-breaking story by the distinguished reporter Malcolm Browne. \u201cIt\u2019s a pretty good story,\u201d I said. \u201cIt\u2019s about the end of the world.\u201d", "The source was Brian Marsden, director of the Central Bureau for Astronomical Telegrams, which is the International Astronomical Union\u2019s clearinghouse for cosmic discoveries, as well as its Minor Planet Center, which is responsible for keeping track of comets and asteroids. He had just calculated that a recently discovered asteroid, a mile-wide rock named 1997 XF11 (now asteroid 35396), would pass within 30,000 miles of Earth on Oct. 26, 2028 \u2014 and had a small but real chance of hitting our planet.", "\u201cIn more than 40 years of computing orbits, I had never seen anything like that before,\u201d Dr. Marsden later said. He felt he had a duty to share this with the world in an I.A.U. Circular.", "The front-page meeting dissolved into a purposeful pandemonium. I spent the rest of the night answering questions from newsroom colleagues who wanted to know whether they should continue to pay their mortgages, and responding to queries and suggestions from the top editors. Astronomers sent pictures of the asteroid, a fuzzy dot in the darkness. I was having an adrenaline-fueled crash course in the scrutiny a front-page story receives in the newsroom before it can be published.", "I didn\u2019t want to go home that night but eventually did, in a nervous fritter. The next morning it was already all over. Pictures of the asteroid from several years earlier had turned up overnight, and Dr. Marsden had recalculated the orbit and found that 1997 XF11 would miss the Earth by 600,000 miles. That was still close by cosmic standards, but safe for civilization.", "In the following days, Dr. Marsden was publicly scolded by his colleagues and the media as a \u201cChicken Little\u201d who had made \u201ccockamamie calculations\u201d without consulting other astronomers who already knew that the asteroid posed no risk. NASA told the astronomers to get their act together before blindsiding the agency and the public with news of an apocalypse.", "Dr. Marsden apologized for generating such a scare, but noted that he had helped raise awareness on the danger of asteroid strikes and extinction.", "\u201cMuch as the incident was bad for my reputation, we needed a scare like that to bring attention to this problem,\u201d he later wrote in The Boston Globe. \u201cI also believe that for us not to make the announcement as we did would have led to condemnation that science was being stripped of its essential openness,\u201d he said.", "I felt bad for Dr. Marsden, a wry, cherubic presence I had known for 20 years of reporting on astronomy. (He died in 2010.) And I felt bad for myself. How often do you get to cover the possible end of the world after only a month on the job? The next day, when The New York Post ran the headline \u201cKiss Your Asteroid Goodbye!,\u201d I took it personally.", "But the incident was indeed a kind of turning point, according to Amy Mainzer, an asteroid expert at the University of Arizona who served as a scientific consultant on \u201cDon\u2019t Look Up.\u201d", "In 2005, Congress ordered NASA to find and begin tracking at least 90 percent of all asteroids larger than 500 feet wide or so that come near Earth. (They neglected to provide much money to pay for the search until years later.) The word was out that we live in a cosmic shooting gallery.", "NASA now spends some $150 million a year on the endeavor. \u201cWe\u2019ve come a long way since 1997 XF11,\u201d said Donald Yeomans, a comet expert at NASA\u2019s Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena who criticized Dr. Marsden back in 1998.", "These days, computers do the work of sorting asteroids and comets, automatically calculating orbits from new observations, comparing them with known objects, scoring them for how dangerous they are and sending out the results to astronomers. Anything that comes within five million miles of Earth is considered a Potentially Hazardous Object, or PHO.", "\u201cWe didn\u2019t have all that back then,\u201d Dr. Mainzer said. \u201cWe\u2019ve learned a lot as a community.\u201d", "\u201cDon\u2019t Look Up,\u201d directed and co-written by Adam McKay, arrives on Friday \u2014 incidentally, less than three weeks after NASA launched a mission to see whether asteroids could be diverted from their trajectories. But the film is less about asteroids than about the tendency of humans to dismiss bad news from science and to embrace misinformation. It was conceived as an allegory about the failure to act on climate change. \u201cA lot of people don\u2019t want to hear it,\u201d Dr. Mainzer said. \u201cAs a scientist, this is terrifying.\u201d", "However, the film was shot, very carefully, during the pandemic, and the parallels to the ongoing health crisis are hard to miss.", "\u201cScientists don\u2019t possess the power to effect change,\u201d Dr. Mainzer said. \u201cHow do we get people to act on scientific information?\u201d Should they \u201cwork within the system,\u201d she asked, even if it means they have to cope with purveyors of misinformation?", "Humor helps, Dr. Mainzer added: \u201cWe\u2019re saying it doesn\u2019t have to be like this. We don\u2019t have to go down this path.\u201d"]
